title: How to Sprout Sweet Potatoes

steps.headline: Pick your sweet potato variety.
steps.description: There are a number of sweet potato varieties, each of which is better suited to different climates and soils. Check your local climate and soil conditions, and talk to a specialist at a nursery or agricultural extension center about what type of sweet potato is best for you. If you live in the US, check your USDA growing zone using the Plant Hardiness Map. This is readily available for reference online. You can sprout the type of sweet potato that you buy in a supermarket. Just keep in mind that it may or may not be the best choice for your region.

steps.headline: Check your sweet potatoes for rot before planting.
steps.description: Before you start sprouting your sweet potatoes, check to make sure they will be viable. Look for pitting, molding, or large areas of soft flesh and discoloration. Any sweet potato showing signs of rot will likely not yield viable sprouts.

steps.headline: Begin your sprouts 60-90 days before the last frost.
steps.description: If you plan to transplant your sweet potatoes into a garden or another outdoor space, plan to plant them 2-3 months before the last frost. This should have your sprouts ready at roughly the right time to plant them in the ground and harvest by the late summer. If you do not plan to transplant your slips outside, you can start them at any time of the year. Just remember that sweet potatoes need a lot of room to grow, and slips generally do not flourish in a pot.

steps.headline: Use a sharp knife to cut your sweet potato in half.
steps.description: Cut the potato through the middle. Do not cut it lengthwise. You should end up with two roughly equal halves with a flat, circular base exposing the potatoes’ flesh. This will be the bottom of your potato half.

steps.headline: Fill a container with warm, fresh water.
steps.description: Fill a watertight glass or ceramic container with at least 1 inch (2.54 cm) of warm, fresh water. You want about half of your sweet potato sections to be submerged. Too little water may prevent them from sprouting, while too much could drown out the sprouts. The water should be at or just a little above room temperature. If the water is too hot, it could scald or hurt your sweet potato.

steps.headline: Place your sweet potatoes flesh-down in the water.
steps.description: Place the exposed flesh of your sweet potatoes down in the water. Try not to overcrowd the container. There should be a little more than a finger width’s worth of distance between potatoes to allow the sprouts to grow.

steps.headline: Keep the container in a warm area.
steps.description: Once your sweet potatoes are set up, place the container in a warm area such as a window sill or near a heat vent. The ideal temperature is around 80° F (about 26.5° C) or slightly warmer. If you do not have a consistently warm area, consider investing in a heat lamp to keep your potatoes warm. You can buy one from most home improvement or gardening stores.

steps.headline: Top off the water regularly for 2-3 months.
steps.description: Check the water levels for your sweet potatoes every day during the 2-3 month sprouting process. If you notice the water levels dropping in your potato container, top it off with some warm, fresh water. Do this only as necessary while your sprouts grow.

steps.headline: Allow your slips to grow until they are around 6 in (15.25 cm) tall.
steps.description: The exact amount of time you will need to grow your sweet potatoes will depend on a number of factors. After around 2-3 months, though, they should be around 6 in (about 15.25 cm) tall with leaves and roots starting to grow. At this point, they are likely ready to transplant.

steps.headline: Remove your sprouts from the sweet potato.
steps.description: Use a knife to carefully remove your slip from the sweet potato at the point where the slip meets the tuber. Try to save as much of the root system as you can. At this point, your sweet potato sprouts should be ready to grow.

steps.headline: Fill a pot with a layer of mulch and a layer of potting soil.
steps.description: To start your sweet potatoes in soil, fill a 1.5 gallon (or a 3.5 liter) pot with a layer of mulch about 3 in (7.62 cm). Follow the mulch with a layer of potting soil, filling up the pot about ⅔ to ¾ full. Make sure your pot has a hole in the bottom for drainage. If you do not have a pot, you can use a disposable roasting pan with holes punctured in the bottom for drainage.

steps.headline: Cover the sweet potato completely in soil.
steps.description: Dig a hole in the center of your pot large enough to fit your whole sweet potato. Place your sweet potato in the hole at about a 45° angle. Then, cover the top of the potato with the soil. Do not cover the potato too much. The soil should just barely cover the potato. This helps keep the sweet potato warm while still letting the sprouts grow easily.

steps.headline: Keep the potatoes warm and moist for 2-3 months.
steps.description: While your sweet potatoes sprout, you will need to keep them warm and moist in the soil. Keep the pots in a warm area. If you are looking to grow your sprouts faster, you can put your pots or pan on a seedling heating mat. This may produce viable sprouts in as little as 3 weeks to a month.

steps.headline: Provide your potatoes with small amounts of water as needed.
steps.description: Your potatoes' soil should be damp but never saturated. Keep monitoring your potatoes and providing them with water as needed until your sprouts have grown to about 6 in (15.25 cm) tall.

steps.headline: Remove your sprouts from the sweet potato.
steps.description: Once your sprouts are long enough, you can use a small, sharp knife to remove them at the point where the stems meet the tuber. From there, you can plant and propagate your sweet potato vines.

text: Readying Your Sweet Potatoes Pick your sweet potato variety. There are a number of sweet potato varieties, each of which is better suited to different climates and soils. Check your local climate and soil conditions, and talk to a specialist at a nursery or agricultural extension center about what type of sweet potato is best for you. If you live in the US, check your USDA growing zone using the Plant Hardiness Map. This is readily available for reference online. You can sprout the type of sweet potato that you buy in a supermarket. Just keep in mind that it may or may not be the best choice for your region. Check your sweet potatoes for rot before planting. Before you start sprouting your sweet potatoes, check to make sure they will be viable. Look for pitting, molding, or large areas of soft flesh and discoloration. Any sweet potato showing signs of rot will likely not yield viable sprouts. Begin your sprouts 60-90 days before the last frost. If you plan to transplant your sweet potatoes into a garden or another outdoor space, plan to plant them 2-3 months before the last frost. This should have your sprouts ready at roughly the right time to plant them in the ground and harvest by the late summer. If you do not plan to transplant your slips outside, you can start them at any time of the year. Just remember that sweet potatoes need a lot of room to grow, and slips generally do not flourish in a pot. Growing Your Sprouts in Water Use a sharp knife to cut your sweet potato in half. Cut the potato through the middle. Do not cut it lengthwise. You should end up with two roughly equal halves with a flat, circular base exposing the potatoes’ flesh. This will be the bottom of your potato half. Fill a container with warm, fresh water. Fill a watertight glass or ceramic container with at least 1 inch (2.54 cm) of warm, fresh water. You want about half of your sweet potato sections to be submerged. Too little water may prevent them from sprouting, while too much could drown out the sprouts. The water should be at or just a little above room temperature. If the water is too hot, it could scald or hurt your sweet potato. Place your sweet potatoes flesh-down in the water. Place the exposed flesh of your sweet potatoes down in the water. Try not to overcrowd the container. There should be a little more than a finger width’s worth of distance between potatoes to allow the sprouts to grow. Keep the container in a warm area. Once your sweet potatoes are set up, place the container in a warm area such as a window sill or near a heat vent. The ideal temperature is around 80° F (about 26.5° C) or slightly warmer. If you do not have a consistently warm area, consider investing in a heat lamp to keep your potatoes warm. You can buy one from most home improvement or gardening stores. Top off the water regularly for 2-3 months. Check the water levels for your sweet potatoes every day during the 2-3 month sprouting process. If you notice the water levels dropping in your potato container, top it off with some warm, fresh water. Do this only as necessary while your sprouts grow. Allow your slips to grow until they are around 6 in (15.25 cm) tall. The exact amount of time you will need to grow your sweet potatoes will depend on a number of factors. After around 2-3 months, though, they should be around 6 in (about 15.25 cm) tall with leaves and roots starting to grow. At this point, they are likely ready to transplant. Remove your sprouts from the sweet potato. Use a knife to carefully remove your slip from the sweet potato at the point where the slip meets the tuber. Try to save as much of the root system as you can. At this point, your sweet potato sprouts should be ready to grow. Sprouting Your Slips in Soil Fill a pot with a layer of mulch and a layer of potting soil. To start your sweet potatoes in soil, fill a 1.5 gallon (or a 3.5 liter) pot with a layer of mulch about 3 in (7.62 cm). Follow the mulch with a layer of potting soil, filling up the pot about ⅔ to ¾ full. Make sure your pot has a hole in the bottom for drainage. If you do not have a pot, you can use a disposable roasting pan with holes punctured in the bottom for drainage. Cover the sweet potato completely in soil. Dig a hole in the center of your pot large enough to fit your whole sweet potato. Place your sweet potato in the hole at about a 45° angle. Then, cover the top of the potato with the soil. Do not cover the potato too much. The soil should just barely cover the potato. This helps keep the sweet potato warm while still letting the sprouts grow easily. Keep the potatoes warm and moist for 2-3 months. While your sweet potatoes sprout, you will need to keep them warm and moist in the soil. Keep the pots in a warm area. If you are looking to grow your sprouts faster, you can put your pots or pan on a seedling heating mat. This may produce viable sprouts in as little as 3 weeks to a month. Provide your potatoes with small amounts of water as needed. Your potatoes' soil should be damp but never saturated. Keep monitoring your potatoes and providing them with water as needed until your sprouts have grown to about 6 in (15.25 cm) tall. Remove your sprouts from the sweet potato. Once your sprouts are long enough, you can use a small, sharp knife to remove them at the point where the stems meet the tuber. From there, you can plant and propagate your sweet potato vines.
sentences: Readying Your Sweet Potatoes Pick your sweet potato variety.
There are a number of sweet potato varieties, each of which is better suited to different climates and soils.
Check your local climate and soil conditions, and talk to a specialist at a nursery or agricultural extension center about what type of sweet potato is best for you.
If you live in the US, check your USDA growing zone using the Plant Hardiness Map.
This is readily available for reference online.
You can sprout the type of sweet potato that you buy in a supermarket.
Just keep in mind that it may or may not be the best choice for your region.
Check your sweet potatoes for rot before planting.
Before you start sprouting your sweet potatoes, check to make sure they will be viable.
Look for pitting, molding, or large areas of soft flesh and discoloration.
Any sweet potato showing signs of rot will likely not yield viable sprouts.
Begin your sprouts 60-90 days before the last frost.
If you plan to transplant your sweet potatoes into a garden or another outdoor space, plan to plant them 2-3 months before the last frost.
This should have your sprouts ready at roughly the right time to plant them in the ground and harvest by the late summer.
If you do not plan to transplant your slips outside, you can start them at any time of the year.
Just remember that sweet potatoes need a lot of room to grow, and slips generally do not flourish in a pot.
Growing Your Sprouts in Water Use a sharp knife to cut your sweet potato in half.
Cut the potato through the middle.
Do not cut it lengthwise.
You should end up with two roughly equal halves with a flat, circular base exposing the potatoes’ flesh.
This will be the bottom of your potato half.
Fill a container with warm, fresh water.
Fill a watertight glass or ceramic container with at least 1 inch (2.54 cm) of warm, fresh water.
You want about half of your sweet potato sections to be submerged.
Too little water may prevent them from sprouting, while too much could drown out the sprouts.
The water should be at or just a little above room temperature.
If the water is too hot, it could scald or hurt your sweet potato.
Place your sweet potatoes flesh-down in the water.
Place the exposed flesh of your sweet potatoes down in the water.
Try not to overcrowd the container.
There should be a little more than a finger width’s worth of distance between potatoes to allow the sprouts to grow.
Keep the container in a warm area.
Once your sweet potatoes are set up, place the container in a warm area such as a window sill or near a heat vent.
The ideal temperature is around 80° F (about 26.5° C) or slightly warmer.
If you do not have a consistently warm area, consider investing in a heat lamp to keep your potatoes warm.
You can buy one from most home improvement or gardening stores.
Top off the water regularly for 2-3 months.
Check the water levels for your sweet potatoes every day during the 2-3 month sprouting process.
If you notice the water levels dropping in your potato container, top it off with some warm, fresh water.
Do this only as necessary while your sprouts grow.
Allow your slips to grow until they are around 6 in (15.25 cm) tall.
The exact amount of time you will need to grow your sweet potatoes will depend on a number of factors.
After around 2-3 months, though, they should be around 6 in (about 15.25 cm) tall with leaves and roots starting to grow.
At this point, they are likely ready to transplant.
Remove your sprouts from the sweet potato.
Use a knife to carefully remove your slip from the sweet potato at the point where the slip meets the tuber.
Try to save as much of the root system as you can.
At this point, your sweet potato sprouts should be ready to grow.
Sprouting Your Slips in Soil Fill a pot with a layer of mulch and a layer of potting soil.
To start your sweet potatoes in soil, fill a 1.5 gallon (or a 3.5 liter) pot with a layer of mulch about 3 in (7.62 cm).
Follow the mulch with a layer of potting soil, filling up the pot about ⅔ to ¾ full.
Make sure your pot has a hole in the bottom for drainage.
If you do not have a pot, you can use a disposable roasting pan with holes punctured in the bottom for drainage.
Cover the sweet potato completely in soil.
Dig a hole in the center of your pot large enough to fit your whole sweet potato.
Place your sweet potato in the hole at about a 45° angle.
Then, cover the top of the potato with the soil.
Do not cover the potato too much.
The soil should just barely cover the potato.
This helps keep the sweet potato warm while still letting the sprouts grow easily.
Keep the potatoes warm and moist for 2-3 months.
While your sweet potatoes sprout, you will need to keep them warm and moist in the soil.
Keep the pots in a warm area.
If you are looking to grow your sprouts faster, you can put your pots or pan on a seedling heating mat.
This may produce viable sprouts in as little as 3 weeks to a month.
Provide your potatoes with small amounts of water as needed.
Your potatoes' soil should be damp but never saturated.
Keep monitoring your potatoes and providing them with water as needed until your sprouts have grown to about 6 in (15.25 cm) tall.
Remove your sprouts from the sweet potato.
Once your sprouts are long enough, you can use a small, sharp knife to remove them at the point where the stems meet the tuber.
From there, you can plant and propagate your sweet potato vines.
tyn_section: Several sweet potatoes, cut in half
